conclusion: To determine if the displacements of Car A and Car B are the same, analyze the areas under their velocity-time graphs.
The area under a velocity-time graph represents the displacement of the object over the given time interval.
The v-t graph shows the velocity of each car as a function of time.
Car A's velocity starts at v2 and decreases to v1 by t1.
Car B's velocity starts at v1 and increases to v2 by t1.
The displacement of each car is given by the area under its velocity-time curve from t = 0 to t = t1.
Since both cars start and end at different velocities but the time interval is the same, compare the areas under the curves.
The figure shows that the area under Car A's curve is different from the area under Car B's curve.
Car A's curve is above Car B's curve for a significant portion of the time, indicating that Car A travels more distance initially.
Car B starts slower but accelerates, covering more distance towards the end.
Although both cars end up at the same final velocity v2, the paths they take to get there are different.
The area under Car A's curve is larger than the area under Car B's curve because Car A spends more time at higher velocities.
Since the areas under the curves are not equal, the displacements of Car A and Car B are not the same.
Final answer: No, the displacements of cars A and B are not the same. Car A has a greater displacement than Car B during the time interval from t = 0 to t = t1.
